description: Introductory course for students in architecture stressing statics, but also covering such topics as fluid flow, waves, electricity, and energy. This course cannot be taken for credit by a student also receiving credit for any physics course numbered 100 or greater.
name: PHYS FOR ARCHITECTS I

values.comments:
This is an introductory course for students in architecture stressing statics, but
also covering such topics as fluid flow, waves, electricity, and energy. This course cannot
be taken for credit by a student also receiving credit for any physics course numbered 100
or greater.
Students say that the course runs very well, with student participation in classes
important, and participation out of class also encouraged. The class is focused on
increasing your general knowledge of all things physics and architecture.
Professor Ashmanskas was described as one of the hardest working professors
students have ever met at Penn. Every week he held study sessions on the material
covered that week and assisted the students in doing homework problems. His
accessibility and willingness to help his students went well beyond what was expected of
an instructor. His experiments were also very entertaining and a great way to see the
material in application.
This course fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement. The prerequisites for
this course include entrance credit in algebra and trigonometry.
